column2: KMartin, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: 4 years on Celexa.  It stopped the intense, uncontrolable, non-stop sobbing.  This drug tamed the excessive ruminating.  My angry, impatient, always-irritable personality was replaced with a sweet mellowness. My suicidal ideations ended. I took this medicine because of some very seriously painful life events. This drug saved my life.The initial side effects: tense jaw, yawning, insomnia, and others, went away fairly quickly.  Celexa kicked in within a week.  This medicine numbed my horribly raw, painful, extremely depressed feelings. I could not stop crying, for literally a year before starting Celexa.  My ruminating was like torture.  I was wonderfully mellow and fairly happy once again.Long term effects included being pretty much emotionless.  I could not cry even if I wanted to.  My passionate, creative characteristics faded away.  I loved to sleep. My ambitions waned. I was definitely sugar coated and in my own little content, semi-zombie world.  But, I really needed that at the time....really, really needed it.I think I gained some weight too while on Celexa.  Hard to pinpoint exactly why.I decided to stop Celexa just 2 1/2 weeks ago.  I am thinking that I might be able to, maybe, not need it anymore.  I am going to try anyway. I want to get some of my old ambition back...my creativity....I miss the good intense feelings of love for my family.  I was kind of flat when it came to that. I was on 40 mg...Took 20mg for a week...then 10 mg for 3 days...now, zero meds. It was easy at first. Now, the brain zaps, whooshes are plentiful.  I feel sad and teary at times.  But that is ok...I am not afraid to cry....I think I just need to get used to emotions again.  I was very nauseous the first 10 days.  That is gone now.  I do have to stomach cramps now.  I am irritable, very tired, and just don't feel so great, overall.  But I am hoping all this will ease away eventually.  I sure am going to give it a good shot!  Quiting smoking was much harder!! LOL!

column2: Shelber, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I was prescribed this med for anxiety after suffering from severe side effects on Effexor. It caused horrendous side effects  and I ended up in the ER after taking it for 17 days (doc said it would all be better after two weeks). I was out sick from work for two week in an attemp to get adjusted to the med. It caused severe night sweeats, sleep disturbance, worsened the anxiety to the point of my brain being completely manic/aggitated and could not concentrate on the minor of things (TV!). It was explained to me by a psych doctor, after the fact, that the reason I had this reaction is because the med is for anxiety AND depression. Since I did not suffer from depression it simply added 'gasoline to the fire' by speeding up my brain - tenfold! Worse than any anxiety I have EVER experienced! I am now on Buspar and have not experienced any side effects.

column2: NeverAgain, 25-34 Male  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: After being diagnosed with a chronic illness I suffered from extreme depression and was prescribed 20mg of Celexa which seemed to work initially.  No sexual interest.  Unable to maintain erection.  Also made me unable to climax.  Eventually the medication seemed to stop working, so my Dr. prescribed 40mg.  Didn't notice much difference other than my abililty to climax returned but my interest in sex is NOT there.  I haven't been able to have sex in a year.  To aide the celexa, and after a suicide attempt, my Dr. also prescribed 150mg of wellbutrin.  This combo proved to be effective for a while with me taking the celexa at bedtime and the wellbutrin in the morning. Eventually that became less effective also so my wellbutrin dosage was increased to 300mg (2 150mg tablets) and I was advised to taper off of celexa by taking 1/2 a tablet at bedtime for a week, then 1/2 tablet every other day.  My withdrawls have been pretty bad...I experience muscle tremors, nausea, vomitting, dizziness, loss of appetite, headaches, and an inability to focus because of the symptoms.  I would recommed exhausting every possible avenue to treat depression without medication because eventually you're left over-medicated, and miserable because of side effects or withdrawls.  I plan to continue tapering off of celexa and then work at tapering off of wellbutrin.  I'm also planning to find a new therapist or some sort of support group, and start going back to church because I still don't feel like I'm living.  I seriously hope something I've said resonates, and helps someone to make an informed decision about their own treatment options.  Gotta go lie down because I just vomitted and my head is pounding.  BE WISE and BE WELL!!!

column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: Status migrainosous was my original diagnosis with overwhelming stress as the primary factor. The Celexa was prescribed to help me get the repeated anxiety under control. As it was very effective, the Celexa really calmed me down to the point where I was to take every other night and now I'm not supposed to take it anymore. I took Celexa for 3 months and am now three days off the drug. I can feel the difference the Celexa made with the treatment of the debilitating migraines. I did suffer with low libido but all SSRI's have this side effect and that was something I could temporarily live with, as long as I didn't have to stay on the medication too long. The decreased dosage to every other day helped with this side effect only a little. Regardless, the Celexa was very effective in the treatment of my anxiety portion of status migrainosous. However when you come off Celexa (like it says), you will have headaches until your body re-adjusts to life without Celexa. I hope I re-adjust soon. Although the anxiety has been reduced with the help of Celexa and stress counseling, the migraines I took it for have come back in force. Not good! My doctor was trying to get me down to 8 migraines a month; I've taken my migraine medicine now 4 times in 3 days. To let you know, however, status migrainosous is very rare and most migraine sufferers will not have to use this product.

column2: Patsy, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: I decided to start taking Celexa after my samples of Lexapro ran out (my insurance didn't cover it). While on celexa I felt numb and very much unlike myself. I was on anti-anxiety meds for one year and decided to go off them due my complete lack of interest in sex and didn't want to deal with what I was experiencing for the rest of my life. I kept thinking there has to be a better way and I tapered off over a 4 week period. Getting off celexa was one of the worst exp. of my life. I had headaches, brain zaps, I was sick to my stomach, nauseous all the time and had horrible mood swings for two full months. About three months after I stopped I had a horrible emotional break down. I was at my wits end and hit the internet to research natural ways to calm me down. After trying 5-htp (which helped a little) my boyfriend mentioned magnesium deficiency. I did a little research on the symptoms and found that all my symptoms pointed towards this. Muscle tension, anxiety and horrible obsessive thoughts, insomnia, etc. After I did a little research on which brand of mag. to buy, I decided on "Slow Mag". I took 4 tabs a day, two in the morning on an empty stomach and two in the evening on an empty stomach. I felt more relaxed and calm within a few hours of taking my first dose; my muscle tension seemed to just melt away. I've been taking slow mag everyday for a few weeks now and I have not felt this good in years! All symtomps I mentioned above are GONE!!! I urge everyone to please, please try mag first before giving in to the drugs our doctors push on us. Magnesium test are rarely able to detect a deficiency, so just give it a try and DO YOUR OWN RESEARCH! There is a large majority of people with this deficiency and don't know it. If you decide to give mag a try, please research brands and make sure you buy a quality supplement that includes calcium. I want to help as many people as I can, you dont have to be a zombie! Good Luck!

column2: 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)

column2: harnessingtheinsanity, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient)
column9: I've been on celexa off and on for 11 years for depression, panic disorder, GAD, etc. I hate to credit a med with giving me my "life" back, but having struggled with these conditions since childhood I have tried everything else known to man and still wound up on meds. Combined with CBT, celexa has brought me down to 10-20 panic attacks a year, as opposed to 10-20 a day. It sedates me a bit, and inspite of diet and exercise I have gained 50lbs on it. Like others have mentioned it has caused increased sweating, dry mouth, slightly decreased sex drive. On the upside,unless i tell them nobody would ever know i suffered from any mental illness. I also responded well for years to Desipramine, ok to lexapro, poorly to prozac, wellbutrin, topamax,and when unmedicated (by choice) found st. John's Wort to be slightly helpful (might help a person with less severe conditions). I would recommend Celexa in spite of some of the bothersome side effects, especially when the alternative in being so seriously ill as to be unable to work, eat, leave the house, socialize, sleep, drive, or even think "clearly". I would say it is one of the more tolerable medications.

column2: willreynolds21, 19-24 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I was diagnosed with Panic Disorder a few months ago, and was in the worst situation of my life. Like so many of the strong people on here, I was fighting for my life with all of the anxiety I had encountered. My doctor prescribed Celexa and Ativan, and let me just say that it really helped me get back on my feet. I was really worried heading back to college that there was no way I'd be able to make it through, but after about a week and a half, closer to two weeks, the celexa began to take effect. For me, and I am the very like cautious and judgemental type, I noticed that the Celexa was helping in the little ways that made a huge difference in my daily lifestyle. In situations when I had normally broken down, I kept my cool and made it through. I would recommend this to anyone who is patient enough to let this drug take its effect in the body system. Since I got on Celexa, 20mg a day, my life has been manageable, something I would never have imagined possible after my rapid onset of panic attacks towards the end of my fall semester in college. A final note though to anyone who does decide to try this medication, it does prompt the ocassional bout of brain fog. You get used to it eventually, but it at times makes you a little "too out of it." Just avoid caffeine at all costs, its not a good component for someone using this medication- makes you ansy. Hope this helps someone.

column2: RaymondOKC, 25-34 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: After taking Celexa for just a couple of weeks, my wife and I both noticed a change in my behavior for the better.  I was less stressed, didn't contemplate negative thoughts as often, and was overall a more "happy" person.  I quote happy because it has always been my belief that depression is cause by actual occurrences in life, and the only way to truly cure yourself of depressive thoughts is to face the things that are difficult to face and "take care of them" thoroughly.  I feel that the drug simply makes things "easier to deal with" than it actually makes you happy or less depressed.  However, after nearly 3 months of drug therapy, I crashed very hard.  No suicidal thoughts, but I was ready to quit my job and divorce my wife even though we have three small children.  This episode didn't last even 24 hours, but it was one of the worst I had experience in my life.  This drug also made me extremely tired.  I simply could not get enough sleep almost as if I were a teenager once again.  After my "crash", I went off of the drug completely cold turkey.  During the first week being off of the drug, I felt almost drunk or high with a fuzzy state of mental being and a constant woozy feeling in my head.  During the second week, I suffered what I will call "brain zaps", nothing painful but once every 1-2 minutes I would get a quick "unbalanced" feeling in my head that would last no more than a second.  It is now early in my third week of being off of the drug, and the brain zaps are waning, but my feeling of lack of good sleep is still very persistent.

column9: After first trying Lexapro and having a positive experience with that drug, I asked my doctor for a switch to Celexa because it has a generic version which is drastically cheaper! Like others who have posted reviews of Celexa, I feel that I have a little less energy than usual, I tire more easily, and my appetite has decreased. These are mild side effects and I do not forsee them causing me to stop taking Celexa. I enjoy the fact that I've lost weight, as it definitely makes me feel good to have people comment on how thin I look! As far as my sex drive, there has been a decrease on my part, but my husband and I did not have sex very often before I started this drug, so it really hasn't been as issue. Overall, I feel much more at ease with life in general. I recommend this drug to others who are dealing with depression.

column2: tlm23, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: I started taking Zoloft after the birth of my son 16 months ago (and I have a history of depression as well). When it wasn't covered by my insurance, I switched to Celexa (citalopram). Worked well for me, but made me feel like a "drone" sometimes - almost too leveled out. Also completely lost sex drive. Decided that I wanted to stop meds in preparation for another pregnancy and also b/c I really don't want to be on them. I stopped cold turkey (after taking 40 mg) and it is STUPID! Do not do it! I would suggest tapering off for sure. I have had migraines, shakiness, tingling hands, dizziness, insomnia and anxiety attacks. WAY worse symptoms than before I started. I have started taking half my dose now after 2 weeks of hell, and I'm hoping to gradually taper off.

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)

column2: bluefontguy, 35-44 Male  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I just wanted to say that everything you read about the difficulties of Celexa withdrawal is true.  My doctor didn't believe it, but I'd read a lot online, and it was absolutely true.  I slowly weened myself off the medication for several months, and still, I got the odd jolting sensations, and otherwise felt very strange for a good several months.  Honestly, I don't think I felt completely normal for a good six months.  I think the drug helped me, but coming off of it was not fun. And honesty, anyone who thinks they're going to stop using it cold turkey is nuts.  Just do what people tell you, slowly ease off of it over a period of months, not weeks, and it will be weird, but eventually you'll be fine.

column2: miserable08, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I have been on this medication for about 3 weeks now and I can no longer stand the side affects. I am on the generic version citalapram. I first was taking the generic version of Zoloft for about 4 months until I ended in the Psychriatric hospital for attmepting suicide. My doctor switched the medication to citalapram at that time and I have experienced the worst side effects, extreme hot flashes through out the day and night, nauseated during the night (severe feeling of vomiting), loss of appetite, food cravings for fast food, lost of interest in exercising ( I use to exercise 5 days per week), difficulty waking up in the morning for work, insomnia (unable to sleep), vivid dreams, nightmares, talking in my sleep (never use to do this before), anxious while at work, lost of interest in my career, depression has increased, and weight gain. Time to change medication and doctor because this is ridiculous. I rather just continue Therapy than take medication. About 4 years ago I had depression really bad and I never had to take medication, only Therapy, Therapy helped me a whole lot. My believes is medications is so overated, Therapy is the answer for me.  I am not happy with my current life on this medication. Good luck to all of you who swear by this medication, as for me I will be taking the Cognitive Behavioral approach to recovery for my depression,anxiety, and panic disorder.

column2: Suy, 35-44 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I've had (undiagnosed) chronic depression as an ongoing background for years. Then last year I landed in a terrible work environment and chose to leave it, in a way that ended rather traumatically. I went to consulting and the shrink freaked out saying I am so depressed I must go on meds now. I was hardly sleeping every night. I went to my M.D. who was also enthusiastic about the treatment. "You will still be yourself", he said. He chose Celexa and put me on a very low dose (10 mg).Well, I bought a month's worth and took it... for six days. Yes, the pain and self-immolation inside my mind were numbed. BUT The last thing I can say is that I was myself. I was definitely NOT.Where to begin?- I am a morning person, off and running as soon as the alarm goes and sometimes a bit before that on most days; suddenly I would roll around in bed unable to switch my mind on for an hour.- My sexual appetite is quite healthy and wide-ranging. Overnight it was simply gone. I had never felt anything like it.- Perhaps worst of all: I am a researcher. I use my brain for a living. I write research articles. But suddenly, by brain became a fuzzball. I could not think for one minute straight. Not because I had other stuff on my mind; because it became a fuzzball.This thing seems to work for other people, maybe they are less sensitive to drugs in general. I know I am, and with all the pain, anger and depression I prefer to be myself than the numb slob I became when on this thing.The good thing about stopping after such a short while is that the "chill-off" period was much shorter. Yet, 3 days after getting off Celexa I had a day of worse depression than I had ever felt. But that was it.Since then I exercise on a daily basis, put a lot of effort into my research, and try to move my life back on track. It will never be easy - but believing that "you can take a pill and it will be better" is in my view no different than becoming a drug addict.

column2: lk, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
kat, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I tried to quit smoking and had another experience with panic & anxiety attacks.  Went to my family dr. who put me on Celexa.  Have had prozac in past with no side effects. Questioned why Celexa,   was told this is better for anxiety. Was on Celexa for 12 days and everyday I became increasingly sicker. Told my doctor and was told these were side effects. Went to a different doc & therapist and both told me I had Serotonin syndrome.(can be fatal)  BE CAREFUL of this drug. My Symptoms were: Increased anxiety, hot flash that started at my lower abdomin and went up to my chin, rapid heart rate, high blood pressure(never had high blood pressure b/4), severe nausea, loss of appetite(couldn't even look at food.(lost 12 lbs in 2 weeks) muscle spasms, couldn't sleep and when tried to sleep the slightest noise made me jump out of my skin. Low grade fever 99.7, massive headache. By day 12 extreme dizziness and couldn't stand up due to weakness and balance loss. It took my body 8 days after stopping Celexa to return to almost normal. After this experience I will try to make it through anxiety without any meds. *Please Note I have learned a lesson from this experience if you have been diagnoised with anxiety or panic disorder I feel we are labeled by some of the  medical profession.  So any complaints or symptoms you experience might not be taken as serious as someone who has not been diagnoised with these disorders.    Please if you feel something isn't right with what's going on in your body listen to yourself and get a second opinion.

column9: IVE BEEN ON CELEXA FOR ABOUT A YEAR.  BEEN ON OTHER ANTIDEPRESSANTS IN THE PAST SUCH AS PROZAC WHICH MADE ME "OUT OF IT"  CELEXA HAS MADE ME ONCE AGAIN ENJOY LIFE WITHOUT THAT FEELING.  SEXUAL SIDE EFFECTS WILL SUBSIDE SHOMEWHAT.  MAKES ME MORE SLEEP MORE BUT ALL IN ALL - GREAT.

column2: mesuba, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: I have GAD and mild depression.  I took Celexa for over a year.  It was very helpful for treating both diseases.  My main issue with the drug were the side effects: restless leg syndrome, insomnia for hours after taking drug and hypersomnia around 8 hours after taking it.  I also noticed that it made me very fidgety, my feet would always be twitching and I could never just sit still.  The fidgeting did not bother me, I'd often not notice it because the movement itself made me feel good (lessened the anxiousness).  The RLS was horrific, I could not sleep at night!  I tried taking it in the morning, but by 6pm I couldn't possibly keep myself awake, so I tried taking it before bed, but even if I was extremely fatigued, taking the med would make me become wide awake and I'd lay in bed for hours trying to fall asleep.  Someone mentioned taking it at lunch which I never tried, but might have been the solution.  Also, if I'd skip more than 2 doses, I would become so depressed to the point of feeling suicidal, which IS NOT ME!  I also gained close to 30lbs while on this med, sometimes gaining 5lbs in one week when my dose was increased.  I also had a lot of muscle fatigue and stiffness.  All in all, if you need it, it works well, I just couldn't take the SE anymore!

column9: My doctor started me on 10mg and I took that for 2 weeks, I noticed nothing.  In fact things got worse.  My anxiety got so bad I had to start taking Ativan to stop the internal jitters. column9: I  began taking Celexa about 3 months ago, and it has definitely helped. I decided to only take 1/2 a pill for a few weeks, then gradually to the whole pill.  Now I am adjusted.  I did stop taking it suddenly, thinking I was pregnant, but I do not recommend doing that!  I have been all emotional, and its like the side effects of coming off are worse than when I began to take it.  Its probably why I thought I was prego.  In all, I didn't think it would make a difference, but it has.  If you are unsure like I was, trust me, it helps.  Everyone around me can feel the difference as well.

column2: shorthandedgoal, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: Depression runs in my family on both sides.  I never knew I was truly depressed until in my late 20's my mother told me that she no longer enjoyed our conversations because I was always such a "downer".  My mother and I are very close and I decided right then and there to do something about it.  Zoloft and Prozac did nothing.  Effexor made me extremely sick to my stomach.  Was on Paxil for quite a while until I met my husband and wanted him to know that my lack of sex drive was not related to him. Wellbutrin put me in such a fog I walked around like a zombie, could not control my extremities and felt like my head was floating above my body.  Along came Lexapro and I was saved!!  Something finally worked well with my body chemistry(an my mother's as well) and didn't cause me strange side effects!!  Being that my insurance did not cover it, my doctor put me on Celexa (Lexapro's cousin) and I have never looked back.  I do not "hide out" or avoid social situations as much as I used to.  I laugh and love to make people laugh.  People that I confide in about taking an antidepresant can not believe that I actually NEED this.  That is how much this has helped me.  Lastly, the only side effect I get is if I forget to take it for a few days I will cry at the drop of a hat.  I will feel like crying over ANYTHING when I skip a dose/doses.  It is then I know I am off my routine... but no other side effects.  Hope this helps someone else.

I have been on Celexa for about 5 years now. The only time I've ever had a problem was when I have missed doses or stopped taking it all-together. One or two missed doses doesn't affect me but any more than that and I notice a big difference in my mood. While on this medication my anger, weepiness, and aggression are all relieved. I recommend it to anyone experiencing these feelings, however, if you also suffer from depression it shouldn't be your only method of treatment. Also, as with any medication, you should take it exactly as prescribed and try not to miss a dose or just stop taking it without consulting your physician.

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: I was taking this medication for 6-7 years for depression.  Instantly, major weight gain occurred and would not come off.  Tired all the time; over time had to increase dosage and then decrease when I got too anxious.  If forgot to take it for a day, sickness (stomach upset, nervousness) would occur.  When I finally decided I did not need it anymore (with my doctor's knowledge); I gradually decreased the dosage.  BE AWARE: There is no going "cold turkey" with this medicine; you will become very physically sick if you do.  I gradually cut back 5-10 mg about every three-five months as I could; then at the lowest dose, went every other day until the medication was finished.  The highest I was at was 60 mg.  It took about 2 years to get off the medication.  It was very tough; there was stomach upset; worry; diarhea; cold sweats; felt like my head was "foggy".  But it can be done.  If you feel you need to get off this medicine; talk to your doctor and give yourself A LOT of time (gradually; at least a year).  I really think your body and mind become dependent on it.  If I could do it, anyone can.  Best of Luck; be blessed.

column2: 45-54 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)

column2: Rose, 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: I started taking Celexa in the AM because it has a tendency to keep me up at night. I would recommend backing off on caffeine if you are taking Celexa in the AM because it gives you a boost and you may feel spacey if you have caffeine along with it. As with any drug, side effects seems worse at first but all of mine on Celexa went away after consistently taking it. I was nauseated at first but after my body got used to the AM routine it went away. Consistency with taking Celexa at the same time every day is what will help you notice a big differece. Like I said, PM doses keep me awake still, but it had no effect on weight, skin, sex drive, or ability to process thought (its actually helped me in all of those areas!)

column9: I have not been on the medication long enough to say for sure whether or not it has completely worked for me yet.  But adjusting to it has been extremely difficult. I was completely miserable and having to work full-time.  It took about 5 1/2 weeks before I felt okay. Without the help of Xanax to calm me down I would never have made it through it. I would have to take .25mg of Xanax with the Celexa every morning and on really bad days a few times throughout the day.  I highly recommend having Xanax or another drug similar on hand incase you have intense side effects. I have been told that I am more sensitive to it than others. column2: Calm inside, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I had gotten depressed and suicidal because of family problems with my children.  It had gotten very bad with crying nonstop and even thinking about how to commit suicide.  I knew I needed help.  The celexa has been very helpful with the suicidal thoughts and the depression, the only things that bother me is I find it very hard to cry and like one of the other reviews I read, I feel numb.  I've only gained 2 pounds and this I believe is from the holiday eating as I've been on the med since September 2007 and just gained the weight in December. Sometimes I feel disconnected from things in life, but then I wonder if feeling normal finally instead of always crying and feeling suicidal and depressed is just taking some getting used to.  I really never had calmness like I do now on the celexa.  I've been on paxil and gained 50 pounds, on wellbutrin and lost weight but never on anything that has helped me this much. I hope I don't have to take this for the rest of my life, but if I do it's better than the life I was living.

column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: It was hard for me to admit I had mild depression and even more difficult for me to begin taking medication for it. I always felt like I should be able to control how I feel. I never felt suicidal, just blah and negative, so I admitted I could feel better and gave in to taking the medication and went to 3 counseling sessions, mainly to accept my depression. It has been a very positive experience for me and the medication has been working. I take 40mg 1x/day and I feel more positive about my life and my interactions with people. I had mild side effects for the first month, dry mouth, yawning, decreased sexual desire, but they went away. I now believe depression is an inbalance of chemicals in the brain because after taking Celexa, my thinking changed. I tried to change it on my own to be more positive, but it always felt like something was blocking me. I have now realized and accepted I have mild depression, and that is what was blocking me and I don't have the power to control it, and it's ok to get help with it.
